Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Oxidative Methods for C-C, C-N, and C-O Bond Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division is supporting Professor Marisa C. Kozlowski of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Pennsylvania to explore the development of methods for the formation of C-C, C-N, and C-O bonds by oxidative coupling reactions. The formation of such bonds by facile oxidative transformations is a well-recognized process in biological systems. Such routes often introduce functionality at non-functionalized centers, thereby eliminating the need for complex pre-functionalized starting materials. To achieve these goals, individual reaction steps will be studied using stoichiometric conditions in order to understand the principles governing novel reactivity and selectivity.

The chemistry studied will contribute to environmentally benign methods for chemical synthesis as oxygen is used as the terminal oxidizing agent in combination with less toxic and less expensive base metals. Successful development of the methodology will have a broad impact as there is an important need for synthetic methods in areas ranging from the pharmaceutical, chemical, materials science, and agricultural industries to basic biological and chemical research endeavors. The broader impacts involve training undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Broadening the participation of underrepresented populations in chemistry research is a particular focus with support for the newly established Association for Cultural Diversity (ACDC) in Chemistry at Penn. This organization is a chapter of the National Consortium for Diversity in Science and Engineering with the mission of promoting diversity of underrepresented minorities in STEM fields at Penn and surrounding universities.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania

POR.DRECONTENT:
By exploring many in reaction in parallel on very small scales (25 microliters total volume), many hypotheses were interrogated rapidly to devise optimal catalytic reaction conditions for a range of organic reactions that involve oxidation of the starting materials to create more complex products from readily available commodity chemicals.  The knowledge gained permitted the design of new, more effective reaction systems enabling generation of new chemical entities for use in biological studies, pharmaceutical synthesis, agrochemical synthesis, and materials chemistry. These reactions were specifically used to generate new compounds for antibacterial study, to synthesize complex natural products in an efficient biomimetic manner, and to generate new compounds for materials studies. Oxygen or air was used as the oxidant to drive these reactions to completion.  Simple catalysts were devised utilizing base metals. Since both oxygen and base metal catalysts are sustainable resources, the results processes have lower environmental impacts.  The data obtained from the parallel screening combined with addition mechanism studies provided fundamental insight that will enable further new discoveries.  High level training in chemical synthesis, parallel microscale screening, and interrogation of chemical mechanism was afforded to a diverse group of high school students, undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral students that will enable them to contribute significantly to the basic research and scientific discovery.


Last Modified: 12/05/2020
Modified by: Marisa C Kozlowski
